title: Post-Radiation Hearing Loss with Functional Overlay
chief_complaint: I have had hearing loss and ringing in my right ear since my radiation treatment in 2009. I am also very sensitive to loud, high-pitched sounds in that ear.

problem_summary.onset: 2009, following radiation therapy to the neck.
problem_summary.course: Patient reports symptoms are greater than onset.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral hearing loss found, though patient emphasizes Right ear symptoms.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Tinnitus (Right ear), Hyperacusis (sensitivity to loud, high-pitched sounds in Right ear).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Sensitivity to sounds and reduced hearing acuity.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Evaluation of hearing status and management of symptoms.

history.present_illness: Patient reports hearing loss and tinnitus in the right ear since radiation to the neck in 2009 for carcinoma of the right tonsil. Reports sensitivity to loud, high-pitched sounds in the right ear starting after therapy.
history.otologic_history: History of right tonsil carcinoma treated with radiation.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Mild SNHL (250-3000 Hz) sloping to severe at 8000 Hz. Left ear: Slight sloping to mild SNHL with a moderate notch at 3000 Hz. Initial testing showed poor reliability with PTA 20 dB poorer than SRT; reinstruction was required to obtain valid organic thresholds.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores align with valid pure-tone averages (after reinstruction). Word recognition scores are excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Present and normal for ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation at 500, 1000, and 2000 Hz. Absent at 4000 Hz. No reflex decay observed.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a mild-to-severe sensorineural hearing loss in the right ear and a slight-to-moderate sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear (with a notch at 3000 Hz). Word recognition ability is excellent in both ears. Initial testing revealed a nonorganic component (functional overlay) where pure-tone thresholds were exaggerated by approximately 20 dB compared to speech thresholds, but valid thresholds were obtained after reinstruction.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows some permanent hearing loss in both ears, which is likely related to your history of radiation therapy.
The initial difficulty in the test was resolved, and we now have a reliable baseline for your hearing.
We recommend an evaluation with an otologist (ear specialist) given your medical history.
For your tinnitus (ringing) and sensitivity to loud sounds, there are management options we can explore.
You should use hearing protection when exposed to loud noise to prevent further damage.
We should schedule an evaluation to discuss hearing aids or assistive devices to help with communication.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is cooperative but perhaps inconsistent in their responses initially.
If the clinician does not give clear instructions, give responses that suggest your hearing is worse than it actually is (functional overlay).
Complain specifically about the right ear and high-pitched sounds being uncomfortable.
